{{Infobox military attack |title= Sayyd Alma Kalay airstrike |image=[[File:Usaf.Boeing B-52.jpg|250px]] |caption=A [[Boeing B-52 Stratofortress]]. |location=Sayyd Alma Kalay, near the [[Arghandab River]], [[Oruzgan Province]], [[Afghanistan]] |target=[[United States]] (friendly fire) |date={{Start date|2001|12|5}} |time= |timezone= |type=airstrike |fatalities=3 Americans and 10 Afghans |injuries=40 |instigator=United States |conflict=the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] }} {{Campaignbox US war in Afghanistan}}
The '''Sayyd Alma Kalayy airstrike''' was a major [[friendly fire]] incident via [[airstrike]] during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001-present)|Invasion of Afghanistan]]. It happened on December 5, 2001 when a U.S. soldier responsible for calling in airstrikes accidentally misguided the Boeing B-52 bomber to strike a hill [[Battle of Sayyd Alma Kalay|held by American Special Forces]] and dozens of their Afghan allies.
== Events ==
Two days earlier, Captain (now Lieutenant Colonel) [[Jason Amerine]] and Afghan tribal leader [[Hamid Karzai]] [[Battle of Sayyd Alma Kalay|fought for the vital Arghandab town of Sayyd Alma Kalay]]. The [[Taliban]] withdrew from the town, and Amerine and Karzai entered the town. After both talked in the headquarters, Amerine left to discuss further airstrikes with another officer. While studying a map, a huge explosion hit the hill near them, apparently from one of their own bombs. Amerine was wounded, while many on the hill were killed or also wounded. A military investigation revealed that one of the men from the headquarters in Sayyd Alma Kalay who arrived earlier in the day made a mistake: he was on the ground calling in airstrikes when he accidentally gave the wrong coordinates for a [[Boeing B-52 Stratofortress]] that dropped the 2,000 lb bomb on the hill on which several Americans and Afghans were proposed.
== Deaths and Wounds ==
Three of Amerine's friends died:
*Master Sergeant Jefferson Davis, 39 years old, of Watuga, Tennessee *Sergeant First Class Dan Petithory, 32 years old, of Cheshire, Massachusetts *Staff Sergeant Brian Prosser, 28 years old, of Bakersfield, California
10 Afghans died as well. Forty Afghans and Americans, including Amerine, were wounded. The wounded were taken to [[Ramstein Air Base]] in [[Germany]] for treatment.
== References == *{{citation|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/campaign/interviews/amerine.html|title=Interviews - U.s. Army Captain Jason Amerine | work = Campaign Against Terror | publisher = PBS - Frontline}} *{{citation|last = Blehm | first = Eric |title = The Only Thing Worth Dying For: How Eleven Green Berets Forged a New Afghanistan}} *{{citation|last = Zullo | first = Allan |title = Battle Heroes: Voices from Afghanistan}}

The '''2003 Italy blackout''' was a serious [[power outage]] that affected all of [[italian peninsula]] for 12 hours and part of [[Switzerland]] near [[Geneva]] for 3 hours on 28 September 2003. It was the largest blackout in the series of blackouts in 2003, involving about 56 million people.
==Causes==
Power went off at about 03:20 hrs. local time on 28 September 2003. Initial reports from Italy's electricity supplier, [[ENEL]], stated that the [[Lukmanier Powerline|power line which supplied electricity to Italy from Switzerland]] was damaged by storms, causing it to trip and also the two 400 kV power lines between [[France]] and Italy to trip due to sudden increased demand from those two power lines. Later, it has been shown that the trip of the first line from Switzerland - the so-called "Lukmanier" line - was caused by a tree flashover. The trigger of the Italian blackout was a sluggish trimming of bushes and trees below HV overhead lines.
The [[Cascading failure|cascading effect]] disrupted power flow to Italy from the two main exporting coutries France and Switzerland. ENEL lost control of the grid in the next 4 seconds, with the lines to neighbouring countries tripped one by one amid the cascading effect. Swiss electricity company [[ATEL]] later concurred that a power line between Switzerland and Italy went out for a few hours.
Frequency dropped down to 49 Hz, due to the loss of import power. Within the next 2,5 minutes, frequency went further down until the under-frequency threshold of 47,5 Hz was hit and all generators were tripped according to the under-frequency protection settings. The reason for the blackout was that during this phase the under-voltage load shedding (UVLS) could not compensate the additional loss of generation, when ca. 7,5 GW of distributed power plants tripped during under-frequency operation (cf. figure "Frequency behaviour in Italy in the transitory period", UCTE report, April 2004, p. 115<ref name="UCTE-report" />).
==Effects==
The night of 27 September 2003 is the night of the annual overnight [[Nuit Blanche]] in [[Rome]], the capital of Italy. Thus, many people were on the streets and all public transportation were still operating at the time of the blackout (at about 3:00 on 28 September 2003) despite the fact that it was very late at night. The blackout caused the carnival to end early. Several hundred people were trapped in [[Rapid transit|underground]] trains. Coupled with heavy rain at the time, many people spent the night sleeping in train stations and on streets in Rome.
Throughout Italy, 110 trains were cancelled, with 30,000 people stranded on trains in the railway network. All flights in Italy were also cancelled. Police described the scene as chaos but there were no serious accidents.
The blackout did not spread further to neighbouring countries, such as [[Austria]], [[Slovenia]] and [[Croatia]], which are connected to Italy. Only part of the [[Canton of Geneva|Geneva Canton]] of Switzerland suffered a power outage for three hours.
==Restoration of service==
After three hours, energy was restored in northern regions. Electricity was restored gradually in most places, and in most cities electricity was powered on again during the morning. [[Rolling blackout]]s continued to affect about 5% of the population on the next two days (29–30 September) as the electricity company ENEL continued its effort to restore supply.
==Official report== The final report of the investigation committee on the 28 September 2003 blackout in Italy was published in April 2004 by [[UCTE#History|UCTE]].<ref name="UCTE-report">[https://www.entsoe.eu/fileadmin/user_upload/_library/publications/ce/otherreports/20040427_UCTE_IC_Final_report.pdf Final UCTE Report, 2004-04-27]</ref>
==Scientific research== Researchers in [[physics]] and [[complex network]]s have modelled the 2003 Italy blackout as a cascade of failures in interdependent networks. Several nodes in the network of power stations failed, causing a failure of the Internet communication network, which in turn caused a further breakdown of power stations. The goal of research was to understand how to build more robust networks.<ref>Sergey V. Buldyrev, Roni Parshani, Gerald Paul, H. Eugene Stanley & Shlomo Havlin. Catastrophic cascade of failures in interdependent networks. ''Nature'' '''464''', 1025-1028 (15 April 2010), http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v464/n7291/abs/nature08932.html</ref> {{see also|network science}}
==See also== * [[Northeast Blackout of 2003]] * [[2015 Turkey blackout]] * [[List of power outages]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/3146136.stm BBC News Online: Huge blackout cripples Italy] * [http://www.bfe.admin.ch/php/modules/publikationen/stream.php?extlang=en&name=en_109363212.pdf&endung=Report%20on%20the%20blackout%20in%20Italy%20on%2028%20September%202003 Official Swiss government report] (.pdf, 171 KB) from 01.Nov.2003 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070311033346/http://www1.appledaily.atnext.com/template/apple/art_main.cfm?iss_id=20030929&sec_id=15335&art_id=3566951 National blackout in Italy (Appledaily Hong Kong)] (in [[Chinese language|Chinese]]) (requires login if accessing outside of Hong Kong)

{{merge from|Qatar–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict|discuss=Talk:2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis#Proposed merge with Qatar–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} The '''2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis''' began in June 2017, when [[Foreign relations of Saudi Arabia#Qatar|Saudi Arabia]], [[Qatar–United Arab Emirates relations|United Arab Emirates]], [[Bahrain–Qatar relations|Bahrain]], [[Egypt–Qatar relations|Egypt]], the [[Maldives]], [[Mauritania]], [[Senegal]], [[Djibouti]], the [[Comoros]], [[Jordan]], the Tobruk-based [[Libya]]n government, and the [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi|Hadi]]-led Yemeni government severed diplomatic relations with [[Qatar]] and banned Qatar airplanes and ships from entering their [[airspace]] and sea routes along with Saudi Arabia blocking the only land crossing.<ref>{{cite web |title=Qatar-Gulf crisis: Your questions answered |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2017/06/qatar-gulf-crisis-questions-answered-170606103033599.html |website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=It’s a boycott, not a blockade |url=https://gulfnews.com/opinion/editorials/it-s-a-boycott-not-a-blockade-1.2043769 |accessdate=August 31, 2018 |work=Gulf News |date=June 14, 2017}}</ref>
The Saudi-led coalition cited Qatar's alleged [[Qatar and state-sponsored terrorism|support for terrorism]] as the main reason for their actions, insisting that [[Qatar]] has violated a 2014 agreement with the members of the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] (GCC).<ref>{{cite news|title=Doha's Actions May Destabilize the Region: Saudi Minister|url=http://newsweekme.com/dohas-actions-may-destabilize-region-saudi-minister/|accessdate=2 July 2017|work=Newsweek ME |date=14 June 2017}}</ref> Saudi Arabia and other countries have [[Al Jazeera controversies and criticism|criticized Al Jazeera]] and [[Iran–Qatar relations|Qatar's relations with Iran]]. Qatar claims that it has assisted the [[Qatar–United States relations|United States]] in the [[War on Terror]] and the ongoing [[military intervention against ISIL]].<ref name=Tamim>{{cite news|title=Sheikh Tamim denies Qatar has links to terrorism|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/region/qatar/sheikh-tamim-denies-qatar-has-links-to-terrorism|date=25 May 2017|newspaper=[[Khaleej Times]]|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref>
Initial supply disruptions were mitigated by additional imports from Iran and Turkey, and Qatar did not agree to any of the Saudi-led coalition's demands.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Collins |first1=Gabriel |title=Anti-Qatar Embargo Grinds Toward Strategic Failure |url=https://scholarship.rice.edu/bitstream/handle/1911/99690/bi-brief-012218-ces-qatarembargo.pdf?sequence=1 |publisher=Rice University’s Baker Institute for Public Policy}}</ref> The demands included reducing diplomatic relations with Iran, stopping military coordination with Turkey, and closing [[Al-Jazeera]].
On 27 July 2017, Qatari foreign minister [[Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani]] told reporters that Egypt, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates and Bahrain were showing "stubbornness" to Qatar and had not taken any steps to solve the crisis. Al Thani added that the Security Council, the General Assembly and "all the United Nations mechanisms" could play a role in resolving the situation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/07/27/qatar-says-un-should-play-role-in-resolving-gulf-crisis.html|title=Qatar says UN should play a role in resolving Gulf crisis|date=27 July 2017|publisher=Fox News Channel|accessdate=30 July 2017}}</ref> On 24 August 2017, Qatar announced that they would restore full diplomatic relations with Iran.<ref>{{cite news|title=Qatar To Reinstate Ambassador To Iran Amid Gulf Crisis|url=http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/qatar-to-reinstate-ambassador-to-iran-amid-gulf-crisis-1741557|date=24 August 2017}}</ref>
==Background== {{Main|Qatar–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict}} {{Further|2017 United States–Saudi Arabia arms deal|Riyadh Summit 2017}}
Since he took power in 1995, [[Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani]] believed Qatar could find security only by transforming itself from a Saudi appendage to a rival of Saudi Arabia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/13/world/middleeast/how-the-saudi-qatar-rivalry-now-combusting-reshaped-the-middle-east.html|title=How the Saudi-Qatar Rivalry, Now Combusting, Reshaped the Middle East|first=Max|last=Fisher|date=13 June 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref> Saudi Arabia withdrew its ambassador to Doha from 2002 to 2008 to try to pressure Qatar to curb its individualistic tendencies. This approach broadly failed.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40159080|title=Qatar row: What's caused the fall-out between Gulf neighbours?|first=Dr David|last=Roberts|date=5 June 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> The [[Arab Spring]] left a power vacuum which both Saudi Arabia and Qatar sought to fill, with Qatar being supportive of the [[revolutionary wave]] and Saudi Arabia opposing it; since both states are allies of the United States, they avoid direct conflict with one another.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/05/world/middleeast/qatar-saudi-arabia-egypt-bahrain-united-arab-emirates.html|title=5 Arab Nations Move to Isolate Qatar, Putting the U.S. in a Bind|date=5 June 2017|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Qatar has had differences with other Arab governments on a number of issues: it broadcasts [[Al Jazeera]]; it is accused of maintaining good relations with Iran; and it has supported the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] in the past.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/05/world/middleeast/qatar-saudi-arabia-egypt-bahrain-united-arab-emirates.html|title=5 Arab States Break Ties With Qatar, Complicating U.S. Coalition-Building|first1=Anne|last1=Barnard|first2=David|last2=Kirkpatrick|date=5 June 2017|accessdate=5 June 2017|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Qatar has been [[Qatar and state-sponsored terrorism|accused of sponsoring terrorism]]. Some countries have faulted Qatar for [[Timber Sycamore|funding]] rebel groups in Syria, including [[al-Qaeda]]’s affiliate in Syria, the [[al-Nusra Front]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/News/12392.aspx|title=Gulf allies and ‘Army of Conquest |newspaper=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]]|date=28 May 2015}}</ref> although the Saudis have done the same.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mazzetti|first1=Mark|last2=Apuzzo|first2=Matt|title=U.S. Relies Heavily on Saudi Money to Support Syrian Rebels|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/24/world/middleeast/us-relies-heavily-on-saudi-money-to-support-syrian-rebels.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=23 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-crisis-turkey-and-saudi-arabia-shock-western-countries-by-supporting-antiassad-jihadists-10242747.html|title=Turkey and Saudi Arabia alarm the West by backing Islamist extremists the Americans had bombed in Syria|author=Kim Sengupta|newspaper=The Independent |date=12 May 2015}}</ref> Qatar has allowed the Afghan [[Taliban]] to set up a political office inside the country.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Robert|title=How Tiny Qatar 'Punches Above Its Weight'|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2013/12/20/255748469/how-tiny-qatar-punches-above-its-weight|publisher=NPR|date=23 December 2013}}</ref> Qatar is [[Qatar–United States relations|a close ally of the United States]], hosting the largest American base in the Middle East, [[Al Udeid Air Base]].<ref name=USbase>{{cite web|last=Lendon|first=Brad |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/05/middleeast/qatar-us-largest-base-in-mideast/index.html |title=Qatar hosts largest US military base in Mideast|agency=CNN|date=5 June 2017|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref>
The exact reasons for the diplomatic break-offs are unclear, but contemporary news coverage primarily attributes this to several events in April and May 2017.
===April 2017 hostage negotiations=== [[File:Flag of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham.svg|right|thumb|250px|Flag of [[Tahrir al-Sham]], a Sunni militant group. Qatar is accused of paying the group $140 million in a deal that saw the release of hostages<ref name="SolomonFinTimes" /> and allowing of humanitarian aid to Shi'ite and Sunni villages in Syria.<ref name=Hostages />]] {{Further|2015 Qatari hunters kidnapping}} In April 2017, Qatar was involved in [[2015 Zabadani cease-fire agreement|a deal]] with both [[Sunni]] and [[Shi'ite]] militants in Iraq and Syria. The deal had two goals. The immediate goal was to secure the return of 26 Qatari hostages (including [[House of Thani|Qatari royals]]) who had been kidnapped by Shi'ite militants while falcon hunting in Southern Iraq and kept in captivity for more than 16 months.<ref name="FA">{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=David |title=A Dustup in the Gulf|journal=Foreign Affairs|date=June 2017 |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/middle-east/2017-06-13/dustup-gulf}}{{subscription required|work=Foreign Affairs}}</ref><ref name=Hostages>{{cite news|title=Big Ransom and Syria Deals Win Release of Royal Qatari Hunters|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/21/world/middleeast/big-ransom-and-syria-deals-win-release-of-royal-qatari-hunters.html?mcubz=2}}</ref> The second goal was to get both Sunni and Shi'ite militants in Syria to allow [[humanitarian aid]] to pass through and allow the safe evacuation of civilians.<ref name=Hostages/> According to the ''[[New York Times]]'', this deal allowed the evacuation of at least 2,000 civilians from [[Madaya, Syria|the Syrian village of Madaya]] alone.<ref name=Hostages/> What outraged Saudi Arabia and the UAE is the amount of money Qatar had to pay to secure the deal. According to the ''[[Financial Times]]'' Qatar paid $700 million to Iranian-backed [[Shia Islam|Shi'a]] militias in Iraq, $120–140 million to [[Tahrir al-Sham]], and $80 million to [[Ahrar al-Sham]].<ref name="SolomonFinTimes">Erika Solomon, [https://www.ft.com/content/dd033082-49e9-11e7-a3f4-c742b9791d43 The $1bn hostage deal that enraged Qatar’s Gulf rivals: Doha reportedly paid al-Qaeda affiliate and Iran to win release of royal hunting party] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170605210800/https://www.ft.com/content/dd033082-49e9-11e7-a3f4-c742b9791d43|date=5 June 2017|title=}}, ''Financial Times'' (5 June 2017).</ref>
===Riyadh Summit 2017=== [[File:Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, King Salman of Saudi Arabia, Melania Trump, and Donald Trump, May 2017.jpg|thumb|left|US President [[Donald Trump]], King [[Salman of Saudi Arabia]], and Egyptian President [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] at the 2017 Riyadh Summit. The meeting is cited as one of the catalysts for the crisis.<ref name=nytimes/>]] As part of the [[Riyadh Summit 2017|Riyadh Summit]] in late May 2017, many world leaders, including US President [[Donald Trump]] visited the region. Trump gave strong support for Saudi Arabia's efforts in fighting against states and groups allied with Iran and the Muslim Brotherhood, leading to an [[2017 United States-Saudi Arabia arms deal|arms deal]] between the countries. The ''Business Insider'' reported that "[[Elliott Broidy]] a top fundraiser for President Donald Trump; and [[George Nader (businessman)|George Nader]], Broidy's business partner ... pushed for anti-Qatar policies at the highest levels of government, and expected large consulting contracts from Saudi Arabia and the UAE."<ref>"[http://www.businessinsider.com/george-nader-elliott-broidy-trump-middle-east-uae-qatar-saudi-arabia-mueller-2018-5 How a top Trump fundraiser spent a year cultivating 2 crown princes to nail $1 billion in business]". ''[[Business Insider]]''. May 21, 2018.</ref> Trump's support may have induced other [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] states to fall in line with Saudi Arabia to take a stance against Qatar.<ref name="nytimes"/> Trump's public support for Saudi Arabia emboldened the kingdom and sent a chill through other Gulf states, including Oman and Kuwait, that fear that any country that defies the Saudis or the United Arab Emirates could face ostracism as Qatar has.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/07/world/middleeast/trump-qatar-saudi-arabia-middle-east.html|title=Trump Has Busy Day in Vortex of Middle East Relations|first1=David E. Sanger, Mark|last1=Landler|first2=Eric|last2=Schmitt|date=7 June 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> The Saudi-led move was at once an opportunity for the GCC partners and Egypt to punish their adversaries in Doha, please their allies in Washington, and remove attention from their own shortcomings and challenges.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inss.org.il/publication/qatar-crisis-causes-implications-risks-need-compromise/|title=The Qatar Crisis: Causes,........... Implications, Risks, and the Need for Compromise|date=13 June 2017}}</ref>
===Hacking of Qatari websites=== According to Qatar-based [[Al Jazeera]] and the American FBI, the [[Qatar News Agency]] website and other government media platforms were [[hack (computing)|hacked]] in May 2017, where hackers posted fake remarks on the official Qatar News Agency attributed to the Emir of Qatar, Sheikh [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]], that expressed support for Iran, Hamas, Hezbollah, and Israel.<ref name=auto>{{Cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/06/saudi-arabia-uae-egypt-bahrain-cut-ties-qatar-170605031700062.html|title=Saudi Arabia, UAE, Egypt, Bahrain cut ties to Qatar|date=5 June 2017|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref> The emir was quoted as saying: "Iran represents a regional and Islamic power that cannot be ignored and it is unwise to face up against it. It is a big power in the stabilization of the region."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/05/23/qatar-says-state-news-website-hacked-fake-article-published.html|title=Hack, fake story expose real tensions between Qatar, Gulf|agency=[[Fox News]]|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="stratfor">"[https://www.stratfor.com/article/trumps-arab-nato-vision-desert-mirage Trump's 'Arab NATO' Vision is a Desert Mirage]". [[Stratfor]]. 31 May 2017.</ref> Qatar reported that the statements were false and did not know their origin.<ref name="nytimes"/> Despite this, the remarks were widely publicized in the various Arab news media, including UAE-based [[Sky News Arabia]] and Saudi-owned [[Al Arabiya]].<ref name=auto/> On 3 June 2017, the [[Twitter|Twitter account]] of Bahraini foreign minister [[Khalid bin Ahmed Al Khalifa]] was hacked.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://phys.org/news/2017-06-bahrain-minister-briefly-hacked-qatar.html |title=Bahrain minister briefly hacked after Qatar cyber attack|publisher=Phys.org|date=3 June 2017|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref>
Initially alleged intelligence gathered by the US security agencies indicated that [[Cyberwarfare by Russia|Russian hackers]] were behind the intrusion first reported by the Qataris.<ref name="PerezProkupecz">{{cite news|author=Evan Perez & Shimon Prokupecz|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/06/politics/russian-hackers-planted-fake-news-qatar-crisis/index.html|title=US suspects Russian hackers planted fake news behind Qatar crisis|agency=CNN|date=6 June 2017|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="Wintour">{{cite news|author=[[Patrick Wintour]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/07/russian-hackers-qatar-crisis-fbi-inquiry-saudi-arabia-uae|title=Russian hackers to blame for sparking Qatar crisis, FBI inquiry finds|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=7 June 2017|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref> However, a US official briefed on the inquiry told the ''New York Times'' that it "was unclear whether the hackers were state-sponsored"<ref name="Landler">{{cite news|author=[[Mark Landler]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/06/world/middleeast/trump-qatar-saudi-arabia.html|title=Trump Takes Credit for Saudi Move Against Qatar, a U.S. Military Partner|work=New York Times|date=6 June 2017|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref> and ''The Guardian'' diplomatic editor [[Patrick Wintour]] reported that "it is believed that the Russian government was not involved in the hacks; instead, freelance hackers were paid to undertake the work on behalf of some other state or individual."<ref name="Wintour"/> A US diplomat said that Russia and its ally Iran stood to benefit from sowing discord among US allies in the region, "particularly if they made it more difficult for the United States to use Qatar as a major base."<ref name="Landler"/> The FBI sent a team of investigators to [[Doha]] to help the [[Qatari government]] investigate the hacking incident.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mofa.gov.qa/en/all-mofa-news/details/2017/06/07/ministry-of-the-interior-statement-on-piracy-crime-on-qatar-news-agency-website |title=Ministry of the Interior Statement on Piracy Crime on Qatar News Agency Website |publisher=mofa.gov.qa |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621122056/https://mofa.gov.qa/en/all-mofa-news/details/2017/06/07/ministry-of-the-interior-statement-on-piracy-crime-on-qatar-news-agency-website |archivedate=21 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Later, the [[The New York Times|''New York Times'']] reported that the hacking incidents may be part of a long-running cyberwar between Qatar and other Gulf countries that was only revealed to the public during the recent incidents, and they noted how Saudi and UAE media picked up the statement made by the hacked media in less than 20 minutes and began interviewing many well-prepared commentators against Qatar.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/08/world/middleeast/qatar-cyberattack-espionage-for-hire.html |title=Hacking in Qatar Highlights a Shift Toward Espionage-for-Hire |last=Kirkpatrick |first=David D. |date=8 June 2017 |work=The New York Times |access-date=11 June 2017 |last2=Frenkel |first2=Sheera |issn=0362-4331 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170610221221/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/08/world/middleeast/qatar-cyberattack-espionage-for-hire.html |archivedate=10 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
US intelligence agencies believe that the hacking was done by the United Arab Emirates, according to a ''[[Washington Post]]'' article published on 16 July.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/uae-hacked-qatari-government-sites-sparking-regional-upheaval-according-to-us-intelligence-officials/2017/07/16/00c46e54-698f-11e7-8eb5-cbccc2e7bfbf_story.html |title=UAE orchestrated hacking of Qatari government sites, sparking regional upheaval, according to U.S. intelligence officials |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729180340/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/uae-hacked-qatari-government-sites-sparking-regional-upheaval-according-to-us-intelligence-officials/2017/07/16/00c46e54-698f-11e7-8eb5-cbccc2e7bfbf_story.html |archivedate=29 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> The intelligence officials stated that the hacking was discussed among Emirati officials on 23 May, one day before the operation took place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/uae-arranged-hacking-qatari-media-washington-post-170717004353563.html |title=UAE arranged hacking of Qatari media: Washington Post |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 July 2017 |accessdate=27 August 2017 |deadurl=no ===Al Jazeera=== In May 2017, the email account of the UAE's ambassador to the US, [[Yousef Al Otaiba|Yousef Al-Otaiba]], was hacked. The emails were reported as "embarrassing" by Al Jazeera,<ref name=embarrass/> because they showed links between the UAE and the [[United states of america|US]] [[neocon]] [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]].<ref name=embarrass>{{cite news |title=Someone Is Using These Leaked Emails To Embarrass Washington's Most Powerful Ambassador |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/otaiba-ambassador-uae-leaked-emails_us_5932bf04e4b02478cb9bec1c |date=3 June 2017 |first=Akbar Shahid |last=Ahmed |work=HuffPost |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603233228/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/otaiba-ambassador-uae-leaked-emails_us_5932bf04e4b02478cb9bec1c |archivedate=3 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Arab countries saw the media coverage of the alleged email hack as a provocation by Qatar, regardless of the lack of affiliation of Qatar to the hack,<ref>{{cite web |title=ANALYSIS: UAE envoy’s hacked emails and Qatar’s escalating Gulf rift |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/features/2017/06/04/ANALYSIS-UAE-envoy-s-hacked-emails-and-Qatar-s-escalating-Gulf-rift-.html |date=4 June 2017 |publisher=Al Arabiya |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731203753/http://english.alarabiya.net/en/features/2017/06/04/ANALYSIS-UAE-envoy-s-hacked-emails-and-Qatar-s-escalating-Gulf-rift-.html |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> and deepened the rift between the two sides.<ref name=FT>{{cite news |title=What is behind the extraordinary Gulf dispute with Qatar? |url=https://www.ft.com/content/3c6b7224-49d0-11e7-a3f4-c742b9791d43 |newspaper=Financial Times |date=5 June 2017 |accessdate=5 June 2017 |subscription=yes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170703000219/https://www.ft.com/content/3c6b7224-49d0-11e7-a3f4-c742b9791d43 |archivedate=3 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 9 June, Al Jazeera's media network was the victim of a [[cyber attack]] across all its platforms.<ref name=Metro6695692>{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/06/08/al-jazeera-hit-by-cyber-attack-on-all-systems-6695692/ |title=Al Jazeera hit by 'cyber attack on all systems' |first=Jen |last=Mills |work=Metro |accessdate=9 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170609005503/http://metro.co.uk/2017/06/08/al-jazeera-hit-by-cyber-attack-on-all-systems-6695692/ |archivedate=9 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Yousef al-Otaiba has been reportedly linked to buy influence for UAE-led campaigns in the White House.<ref name=FT2>{{cite news |title=Why UAE ambassador is so much influential in DC |url=https://theintercept.com/2017/07/30/uae-yousef-otaiba-cnas-american-progress-michele-flournoy-drone |newspaper=The Intercept |date=5 June 2017 |accessdate=5 June 2017 |subscription=yes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730133741/https://theintercept.com/2017/07/30/uae-yousef-otaiba-cnas-american-progress-michele-flournoy-drone/ |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>

Saudi Arabia and the UAE notified ports and shipping agents not to receive Qatari vessels or ships owned by Qatari companies or individuals.<ref name="aljazeera1/6june2017" /> Saudi Arabia closed the border with Qatar.<ref name="aljazeera1/6june2017" /> Saudi Arabia restricted its airspace to [[Qatar Airways]]. Instead, Qatar was forced to reroute flights to Africa and Europe through Iranian airspace.<ref name="auto1">{{cite news |title=Saudi-led Rupture With Qatar Pushes Nation into Iran's Embrace |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-06/saudi-led-rupture-with-qatar-pushes-nation-into-iran-s-embrace |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170607085920/https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-06/saudi-led-rupture-with-qatar-pushes-nation-into-iran-s-embrace |archivedate=7 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Saudi Arabia's central bank advised banks not to trade with Qatari banks in [[Qatari riyal]]s.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-saudi-banks-idUSKBN18X0S9 "Saudi central bank tells banks not to trade with Qatar banks in Qatari riyals: sources"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003175217/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-saudi-banks-idUSKBN18X0S9 |date=3 October 2017 }}. Reuters</ref>
Qatar verbally criticized the ban. The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Qatar)|Foreign Ministry of Qatar]] criticized the ban, arguing that it undermined Qatar's sovereignty.<ref name="dawn/5june2017"/> The foreign minister of Qatar, [[Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani]], said that Saudi statements regarding Qatar were contradictory: on the one hand, Saudi Arabia claimed Qatar was supporting Iran, on the other hand, it claimed Qatar was funding [[Sunni]] extremists fighting against Iran.<ref>{{cite news |title=Qatar: We're 'willing to talk' to resolve diplomatic crisis |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/06/middleeast/qatar-diplomatic-crisis/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606101325/http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/06/middleeast/qatar-diplomatic-crisis/ |archivedate=6 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Saudi Arabia's move was welcomed by United States president [[Donald Trump]] despite a large US presence at the [[Al Udeid Air Base]], the primary base of US air operations against the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-07/trump-s-qatar-curveball-makes-tillerson-improvise-policy-again |title=Trump's Qatar Curveball Makes Tillerson Improvise Policy Again |date=7 June 2017 |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |accessdate=10 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826025948/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-07/trump-s-qatar-curveball-makes-tillerson-improvise-policy-again |archivedate=26 August 2017 |df=dmy-all}}<br/>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/06/06/for-qataris-a-u-s-air-base-is-best-defense-against-trump-attacks/ |title=For Qataris, a U.S. air base is best defense against Trump attacks |first1=Greg |last1=Jaffe |first2=Thomas |last2=Gibbons-Neff |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=10 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170707090451/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/06/06/for-qataris-a-u-s-air-base-is-best-defense-against-trump-attacks/ |archivedate=7 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, Secretary of State [[Rex Tillerson|Rex W. Tillerson]] and Defense Secretary [[James Mattis]] worked on de-escalating the situation.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-07/trump-s-qatar-curveball-makes-tillerson-improvise-policy-again |title=Trump's Qatar Curveball Makes Tillerson Improvise Policy Again |date=7 June 2017 |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |access-date=5 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826025948/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-07/trump-s-qatar-curveball-makes-tillerson-improvise-policy-again |archivedate=26 August 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Tillerson, as the CEO of [[ExxonMobil]], was acquainted with the current and previous emirs of Qatar.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Overdahl |first1=Stian |title=Saudi and UAE Stumble Over Tiny Qatar |url=https://magazine.zenith.me/en/politics/pyrrhic-manoeuvres-among-gulf-states |accessdate=16 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170828160937/https://magazine.zenith.me/en/politics/pyrrhic-manoeuvres-among-gulf-states |archivedate=28 August 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> A number of countries in the region, including [[Qatar–Turkey relations|Turkey]], [[Qatar–Russia relations|Russia]] and [[Iran–Qatar relations|Iran]], called for the crisis to be resolved through peaceful negotiations.

|url=https://apnews.com/8257ce650e224188a1884e34eabb5e90/4-Arab-nations-cut-diplomatic-ties-to-Qatar-as-rift-deepens |title=Arab nations cut ties with Qatar in new Mideast crisis |last=Gambrell Hassan al-Thawadi, secretary general of the Qatar World Cup supreme committee, has stated that the projects are going as scheduled for the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]]. Qatar's only land border and air and sea routes have been cut off by [[Bahrain]], [[Egypt]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE). As the blockade came into play, World Cup organizers were asked to investigate a "Plan B", [[FIFA]] however has confidence in not exploring a "Plan B" for an alternate 2022 host. According to Thawadi, all these logistical obstacles are being overcome and building progress is continuing with only minimal cost increases, in preparation for the first World Cup in the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/gulf-blockade-poses-risk-qatar-world-cup-171006210428080.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=8 October 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171008154735/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/gulf-blockade-poses-risk-qatar-world-cup-171006210428080.html |archivedate=8 October 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Reactions ==
===Global reactions=== [[Israel]]'s defence minister, [[Avigdor Lieberman]], described the situation as an "opportunity" for Israel, stating, "Some [Arab countries'] interests overlap with Israeli interests, including the issue with al-Jazeera." He went on to describe al-Jazeera as an "incitement machine" and "pure propaganda". Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] has demanded al-Jazeera shut down its offices in Israel.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-demands-al-jazeera-offices-in-israel-be-shut-down/ |title=Netanyahu demands al-Jazeera offices in Israel be shut down |website=The Times of Israel |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170727013412/http://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-demands-al-jazeera-offices-in-israel-be-shut-down/ |archivedate=27 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Reports that [[Mauritius]] had cut ties with Qatar were refuted by the Mauritian government.<ref name="IONNews">{{cite news |url=http://ionnews.mu/maurice-maintient-ses-relations-diplomatiques-avec-le-qatar-060617/ |title=Maurice maintient ses relations diplomatiques avec le Qatar |trans-title=Mauritius maintains its diplomatic relations with Qatar |agency=Indian Ocean News Network |date=6 June 2017 |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170703201410/http://ionnews.mu/maurice-maintient-ses-relations-diplomatiques-avec-le-qatar-060617/ |archivedate=3 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="DefiMedia">{{cite news |url=http://defimedia.info/diplomatie-maurice-maintient-ses-liens-avec-le-qatar |title=Diplomatie : Maurice maintient ses liens avec le Qatar |trans-title=Diplomacy: Mauritius maintains its links with Qatar |agency=[[Le Défi Media Group]] |date=7 June 2017 |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170717090106/http://defimedia.info/diplomatie-maurice-maintient-ses-liens-avec-le-qatar |archivedate=17 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> A report in the ''[[Saudi Gazette]]'' incorrectly stated that Mauritius had broken off ties with Qatar and that [[Vice Prime Minister of Mauritius|Mauritius' Vice Prime-Minister]] had issued a communiqué pledging his country's support for Saudi Arabia. This prompted further erroneous reports by other outlets. However, Mauritian [[Vice Prime Minister of Mauritius|Vice Prime Minister]] Showkutally Soodhun in an interview with [[Le Défi Media Group]] of Mauritius refuted claims that he had issued any such communiqué, and [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Mauritius)|Mauritius' Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] issued a statement that Mauritius continued to maintain diplomatic relations with Qatar.<ref name="IONNews"/><ref name="DefiMedia"/>
[[Pakistan]] stated that it had no plans to cut diplomatic relations with Qatar.<ref>{{cite news |title=Pakistan has no plans to cut diplomatic ties with Qatar: FO |url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1427775/pakistan-no-plans-cut-diplomatic-ties-qatar-fo/ |accessdate=5 June 2017 |work=The Express Tribune |date=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170605095833/https://tribune.com.pk/story/1427775/pakistan-no-plans-cut-diplomatic-ties-qatar-fo/ |archivedate=5 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Members of the Parliament passed a resolution in [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] urging all countries to "show restraint and resolve their differences through dialogue".<ref name="auto2"/> Federal minister for Petroleum and Natural Resources said that "Pakistan will continue to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Qatar."<ref>{{cite news |title=Pakistan to continue import of LNG from Qatar |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1338261/pakistan-to-continue-import-of-lng-from-qatar |accessdate=8 June 2017 |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |date=8 June 2017 |language=en |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170609040058/https://www.dawn.com/news/1338261/pakistan-to-continue-import-of-lng-from-qatar |archivedate=9 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> A six-member Qatari delegation headed by a special envoy of the Qatari Emir visited Pakistan and asked Pakistan to play a positive role in resolving the diplomatic crisis. Prime Minister of Pakistan [[Nawaz Sharif]] said "Pakistan would do "all it can" to help resolve the crisis and called on the Muslim world to play a role in ending hostilities."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Siddiqui |first1=Dawn.com |title=Delegation headed by special envoy of Qatari Emir makes short visit to Pakistan |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1338268/delegation-headed-by-special-envoy-of-qatari-emir-makes-short-visit-to-pakistan |accessdate=8 June 2017 |work=Dawn|location=Pakistan |date=8 June 2017 |language=en |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003180039/https://www.dawn.com/news/1338268/delegation-headed-by-special-envoy-of-qatari-emir-makes-short-visit-to-pakistan |archivedate=3 October 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Turkish Radio and Television Corporation|TRT]] in a report said that Pakistan would deploy 20,000 troops in Qatar but the Pakistani foreign ministry denied the report.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2017/06/11/Pakistan-denies-media-reports-of-troop-deployment-to-Qatar.html |title=Pakistan denies media reports of troop deployment to Qatar |accessdate=11 June 2017 |publisher=Al Arabiya Network |date=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003174927/http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2017/06/11/Pakistan-denies-media-reports-of-troop-deployment-to-Qatar.html |archivedate=3 October 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The [[Philippines]] suspended the deployment of migrant workers to Qatar on 6 June 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Philippines bans deployment of workers to Qatar |url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2017/06/06/philippines-bans-deployment-workers-qatar-545962 |accessdate=6 June 2017 |work=Sun Star Manila |agency=HDT, SunStar Philippines |date=6 June 2017}}</ref> However,the next day, they allowed the deployment of returning workers and those with an Overseas Employment Certificate, but still maintained the suspension of the deployment of new workers.<ref>{{cite news |title=PHL partially lifts suspension of OFW deployment to Qatar |publisher=GMA network |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/pinoyabroad/613610/phl-partially-lifts-ban-on-ofw-deployment-to-qatar/story/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170717145919/http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/pinoyabroad/613610/phl-partially-lifts-ban-on-ofw-deployment-to-qatar/story/ |archivedate=17 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> The suspension was later fully lifted on 15 June.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jaymalin |first1=Mayen |title=DOLE lifts suspension of OFW deployment in Qatar |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/06/16/1710495/dole-lifts-suspension-ofw-deployment-qatar |accessdate=16 June 2017 |work=The Philippine Star |date=16 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170615191514/http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/06/16/1710495/dole-lifts-suspension-ofw-deployment-qatar |archivedate=15 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[File:Donald Trump meets with the Emir of Qatar (Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani), May 2017.jpg|thumb|[[United States President]] [[Donald Trump]] with the [[Emir of Qatar]] [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]], May 2017]] [[United States]] President [[Donald Trump]] claimed credit for engineering the diplomatic crisis in a [[Donald Trump on social media|series of tweets]].<ref name=credit>{{cite news |publisher=BBC |title=Qatar row: Trump claims credit for isolation |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40175935 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170607013027/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40175935 |archivedate=7 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 6 June, Trump began by tweeting: "During my recent trip to the Middle East I stated that there can no longer be funding of Radical Ideology. Leaders pointed to Qatar – look!"<ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |last=Trump |first=Donald J. |number=872062159789985792 |date=6 June 2017 |title=During my recent trip to the Middle East I stated that there can no longer be funding of Radical Ideology. Leaders pointed to Qatar – look! |link=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/872062159789985792 |access-date=7 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606120637/https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/872062159789985792 |archive-date=6 June 2017 |dead-url= no}}</ref><ref name= credit /> An hour and a half later, he remarked on Twitter that it was "good to see the Saudi Arabia visit with the King and 50 countries already paying off. They said they would take a hard line on funding extremism, and all reference{{sic}} was pointing to Qatar. Perhaps this will be the beginning of the end to the horror of terrorism!"<ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |last=Trump |first=Donald J. |number=872084870620520448 |date=6 June 2017 |title=So good to see the Saudi Arabia visit with the King and 50 countries already paying off. They said they would take a hard line on funding... |link=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/872084870620520448 |access-date=7 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606133708/https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/872084870620520448 |archive-date= 6 June 2017 |dead-url= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |last=Trump |first=Donald J. |number=872086906804240384 |date=6 June 2017 |title=...extremism, and all reference was pointing to Qatar. Perhaps this will be the beginning of the end to the horror of terrorism! |link=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/872086906804240384 |access-date= 7 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606134456/https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/872086906804240384 |archive-date= 6 June 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name= "WaPo 6 June"/> This was in contrast to attempts by [[the Pentagon]] and the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] to remain neutral. The Pentagon praised Qatar for hosting the [[Al Udeid Air Base]] and for its "enduring commitment to regional security." [[United States Ambassador to Qatar|US Ambassador to Qatar]], [[Dana Shell Smith]], sent a similar message.<ref>{{cite news |title=U.S. military praises Qatar, despite Trump tweet |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-usa-pentagon-idUSKBN18X2G2 |accessdate=8 June 2017 |agency=Reuters |date=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 8 June, President Donald Trump, during a phone call with the [[Emir of Qatar]] [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]], offered to act as a mediator in the conflict with a White House Qatari official stated, "The emir has no plans to leave Qatar while the country is under a blockade."<ref name="auto3">{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-idUSKBN18Z1C9 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-qatar-terrorism-funding-saudi-arabia-gulf-accusation-very-high-level-a7782896.html |accessdate=10 June 2017 |work=The |archivedate=9 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> This statement was in conflict with Secretary of State Tillerson's comments on the same day, which called on Gulf states to ease the blockade.<ref And I think we had a huge impact."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/transcript/2017/06/21/conway-special-elections-reaffirmation-trumps-agenda-sekulow-investigation-should-include-comeys-leak.html |title=Conway: Special elections a reaffirmation of Trump's agenda; Sekulow: Investigation should include Comey's leak |date=21 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170630215456/http://www.foxnews.com/transcript/2017/06/21/conway-special-elections-reaffirmation-trumps-agenda-sekulow-investigation-should-include-comeys-leak.html |archivedate=30 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="auto8">{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-qatar-list-20170623-story.html |title=Will Qatar agree to Arab countries' new list of demands? Unlikely |first=Molly |last=Hennessy-Fiske |date=23 June 2017 |work=Los Angeles Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170630180620/http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-qatar-list-20170623-story.html |archivedate=30 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 8 June 2017, Egypt's deputy [[United Nations|UN]] Ambassador Ihab Moustafa called for the [[United Nations Security Council]] to launch an investigation into accusations that Qatar "paid up to $1 billion to a terrorist group active in Iraq" to free 26 Qatari hostages, including members of its royal family, which payment would violate UN resolutions. The Qataris were kidnapped on 16 December 2015 from a desert camp for falcon hunters in [[southern Iraq]]. The hostages were released eighteen months later in April 2017. Qatari diplomats responded to the Egyptian calls for an investigation by reaffirming their commitment to the UN resolutions towards eliminating the financing of terrorism.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-un-idUSKBN18Z26W |title=Egypt calls for U.N. inquiry into accusation of Qatar ransom payment |date=8 June 2017 |agency=Reuters |access-date=8 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608222124/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-un-idUSKBN18Z26W |archivedate=8 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/latest-qatar-releases-initial-report-alleged-hack-47904088 |title=The Latest: Egypt seeks UN probe of alleged Qatar ransom |last=News |first=ABC |publisher=ABC News |access-date=8 June 2017 |language=en |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608042824/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/latest-qatar-releases-initial-report-alleged-hack-47904088 |archivedate=8 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In June 2017, the government of Qatar hired American attorney and politician [[John Ashcroft]] to lobby on its behalf and help the state deny international allegations of supporting terror.<ref>{{cite web |title=Qatar, accused of supporting terrorism, hires ex-U.S. attorney general – Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-ashcroft-idUSKBN1910T6 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=10 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170610181957/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-ashcroft-idUSKBN1910T6 |archivedate=10 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Singled Out by Trump, Qatar Hires Former Top U.S. Law Man – Bloomberg |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-10/singled-out-by-trump-qatar-hires-former-top-law-man-to-lobby |website=BloombergPolitics |accessdate=10 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170610041552/https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-10/singled-out-by-trump-qatar-hires-former-top-law-man-to-lobby |archivedate=10 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Qatar blockade: Iran sends five planeloads of food – BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40237721 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170612040431/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40237721 |archivedate=12 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Qatar Hires Former U.S. Attorney General To Rebut Terrorism Allegations |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/qatar-hires-lawyer-boycott-terrorism-allegations-saudis-trump/28539933.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |accessdate=10 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170610205539/https://www.rferl.org/a/qatar-hires-lawyer-boycott-terrorism-allegations-saudis-trump/28539933.html |archivedate=10 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 24 November 2017, UAE's head of security, [[Lieutenant General]] Dhahi Khalfan, blamed the [[2017 Sinai attack]] on [[Al-Jazeera]]'s reporting and called for the bombing of Al-Jazeera's headquarters by the Saudi-led coalition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/dubai-security-chief-calls-bombing-al-jazeera-171125143439231.html|title=Dubai security chief calls for bombing of Al Jazeera|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13960905000275|title=Farsnews|website=en.farsnews.com}}</ref>
== Impact ==
===Logistical implications===
On 6 June 2017, [[Emirates Post]] of UAE, halted postal services to Qatar.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/emirates-post-group-halts-services-qatar-677207.html |title=Emirates Post Group halts services to Qatar |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170609072905/http://www.arabianbusiness.com/emirates-post-group-halts-services-qatar-677207.html |archivedate=9 June 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Nearly 80 percent of Qatar's food requirements come from Gulf Arab neighbors, with only 1 percent being produced domestically and even imports from outside the Gulf states usually crossing the now closed land border with Saudi Arabia.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Adam |title=Analysis {{!}} Qatar could face a food crisis in spat with Arab neighbors|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/06/05/qatar-could-face-a-food-crisis-in-spat-with-arab-neighbors/|accessdate=7 June 2017|work=The Washington Post|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606222639/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/06/05/qatar-could-face-a-food-crisis-in-spat-with-arab-neighbors/|archivedate=6 June 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Immediately after the cutting of relations, local reports indicated residents [[Panic buying|swarmed]] grocery stores in hopes of stockpiling food. Many food delivery trucks were idled along the Saudi-Qatari border. On 8 June 2017, Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani]] said, "We're not worried about a food shortage, we're fine. We can live forever like this, we are well prepared." Qatar has been in talks with both Turkey and Iran to secure supply of water and food. On 11 June 2017, Iran sent four cargo planes with fruit and vegetables and promised to continue the supply.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-iran-idUSKBN1920EG?il=0 |title=Iran flies food to Qatar amid concerns of shortages |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=11 June 2017 |access-date=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003174716/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-iran-idUSKBN1920EG?il=0 |archivedate=3 October 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Turkey has pledged food and water supplies to go along with their troop deployment at their [[Turkish military]] base in Qatar.<ref name="auto3"/>
As part of the Qatari government's response to lost food imports, it provided support to domestic agricultural company [[Baladna (company)|Baladna]], which built a new dairy farm with imported cattle that was planned to produce enough milk to fulfill domestic demand for dairy products by June 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-cows/qatar-builds-dairy-industry-in-desert-as-it-defies-arab-boycott-idUSKBN1DT2E9 | title=Qatar builds dairy industry in desert as it defies Arab boycott | publisher=Reuters | date=29 November 2017 | accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref>{{update-inline|date=September 2018}}

|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-05/saudi-led-alliance-cuts-qatar-ties-as-gulf-crisis-escalates |title=Flights Grounded as Gulf Split on Iran Leaves Qatar Isolated |last=Carey |dead-url=no |last2=Fattah |first2=Zainab |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.emirates.com/ae/english/about/operational_updates/operational_updates.aspx#/#4258319 [[EgyptAir]],<ref>{{cite news |title=EgyptAir Suspends Flights to Qatar Until Special Notice |url=https://sputniknews.com/middleeast/201706051054314335-egyptair-suspends-flights-to-qatar/ |date=5 June [[FlyDubai]], [[Air Arabia]], [[Saudi Arabian Airlines]] and [[Etihad Airways]] suspended their flights to and from Qatar.<ref name="aljazeera/5june2017">{{cite news |title=Qatar diplomatic crisis: Bahrain,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blog.flightradar24.com/blog/flight-ban-for-qatar-flights-in-uae-saudi-arabia-bahrain-and-egypt/|title=Flight Ban for Qatar Flights in UAE, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain,
