{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use American English|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Sudden infant death syndrome | synonyms = Cot death, crib death | image = Safe Sleep logo.svg | caption = [[Safe to Sleep]] logo | field = [[Pediatrics]] | symptoms = [[Death]] of a child less than one year of age | complications = | onset = Sudden | duration = | types = | causes = Unknown | risks = Sleeping on the stomach or side, overheating, exposure to [[tobacco smoke]], [[bed sharing]] | diagnosis = No cause found after an investigation and [[autopsy]] | differential = [[Infection]]s, [[genetic disorder]]s, heart problems, [[child abuse]] | prevention = Putting newborns on their back to sleep, [[pacifier]], [[breastfeeding]], [[immunization]] | treatment = Support for families | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = 1 in 1,000–10,000 | deaths = }} [[File:Sudden infant death syndrome.webm|thumb|upright=1.36|Video explanation]] '''Sudden infant death syndrome''' ('''SIDS'''), also known as '''cot death''' or '''crib death''', is the sudden unexplained [[death]] of a child less than one year of age.{{cite web|title=Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS): Overview|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/Pages/default.aspx|website=National Institute of Child Health and Human Development|accessdate=9 March 2015|date=27 June 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223190134/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/Pages/default.aspx|archivedate=23 February 2015|df=}} Diagnosis requires that the death remains unexplained even after a thorough [[autopsy]] and detailed death scene investigation.{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/sids/|title=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Sudden Infant Death|accessdate=March 13, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318045725/http://www.cdc.gov/sids/|archivedate=March 18, 2013|df=}} SIDS usually occurs during [[sleep]]. Typically death occurs between the hours of 00:00 and 09:00.{{cite book|last1=Optiz|first1=Enid Gilbert-Barness, Diane E. Spicer, Thora S. Steffensen ; foreword by John M.|title=Handbook of pediatric autopsy pathology|date=2013|publisher=Springer New York|location=New York, NY|isbn=9781461467113|page=654|edition=Second edition.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yaPjAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA654|df=}} There is usually no evidence of struggle and no noise produced.{{cite book|last1=Scheimberg|first1=edited by Marta C. Cohen, Irene|title=The Pediatric and perinatal autopsy manual|date=2014|isbn=9781107646070|page=319|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t33sAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA319|df=}} The exact cause of SIDS is unknown.{{cite web|title=What causes SIDS?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/conditioninfo/pages/causes.aspx|website=National Institute of Child Health and Human Development|accessdate=9 March 2015|date=12 April 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402220510/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/conditioninfo/pages/causes.aspx|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}} The requirement of a combination of factors including a specific underlying susceptibility, a specific time in development, and an environmental stressor has been proposed.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kinney HC, Thach BT | title = The sudden infant death syndrome | journal = N. Engl. J. Med. | volume = 361 | issue = 8 | pages = 795–805 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19692691 | pmc = 3268262 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMra0803836 }} These environmental stressors may include sleeping on the stomach or side, overheating, and exposure to [[tobacco smoke]]. Accidental suffocation from [[bed sharing]] (also known as co-sleeping) or soft objects may also play a role.{{cite web|title=Ways To Reduce the Risk of SIDS and Other Sleep-Related Causes of Infant Death|url=https://www.nichd.nih.gov/sts/about/risk/Pages/reduce.aspx|website=NICHD|accessdate=2 March 2016|date=20 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307132750/https://www.nichd.nih.gov/sts/about/risk/Pages/reduce.aspx|archivedate=7 March 2016|df=}} Another risk factor is being born before 39 [[weeks of gestation]]. SIDS makes up about 80% of sudden and unexpected infant deaths (SUIDs). Other causes include [[infection]]s, [[genetic disorder]]s, and heart problems. While [[child abuse]] in the form of intentional [[asphyxia|suffocation]] may be misdiagnosed as SIDS, this is believed to make up less than 5% of cases. The most effective method of reducing the risk of SIDS is putting a child less than one year old on their back to sleep. Other measures include a firm mattress separate from but close to caregivers, no loose bedding, a relatively cool sleeping environment, using a [[pacifier]], and avoiding exposure to tobacco smoke.{{cite journal |vauthors=Moon RY, Fu L | title = Sudden infant death syndrome: an update. | journal = Pediatrics in Review | volume = 33 | issue = 7 | pages = 314–20 | date = July 2012 | pmid = 22753789 | doi = 10.1542/pir.33-7-314 }} [[Breastfeeding]] and [[immunization]] may also be preventive. Measures not shown to be useful include positioning devices and [[baby monitors]].{{cite web|title=How can I reduce the risk of SIDS?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/conditioninfo/pages/reduce-risk.aspx|website=National Institute of Child Health and Human Development|accessdate=9 March 2015|date=22 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227031841/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/conditioninfo/pages/reduce-risk.aspx|archivedate=27 February 2015|df=}} Evidence is not sufficient for the use of fans. Grief support for families affected by SIDS is important, as the death of the infant is sudden, without witnesses, and often associated with an investigation. Rates of SIDS vary nearly tenfold in [[developed countries]] from one in a thousand to one in ten thousand. Globally it resulted in about 19,200 deaths in 2015 down from 22,000 deaths in 1990.{{cite journal|last1=GBD 2013 Mortality and Causes of Death|first1=Collaborators|title=Global, regional, and national age-sex specific all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 240 causes of death, 1990–2013: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013.|journal=Lancet|date=17 December 2014|pmid=25530442|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)61682-2|volume=385|pages=117–71|pmc=4340604}}{{cite journal|last1=GBD 2015 Mortality and Causes of Death|first1=Collaborators.|title=Global, regional, and national life expectancy, all-cause mortality, and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes of death, 1980-2015: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015.|journal=Lancet|date=8 October 2016|volume=388|issue=10053|pages=1459–1544|pmid=27733281|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(16)31012-1|pmc=5388903}} SIDS was the third leading cause of [[infant mortality|death in children less than one year old]] in the United States in 2011.{{cite journal |vauthors=Hoyert DL, Xu JQ |title=Deaths: Preliminary data for 2011 |journal=National vital statistics reports. |volume=61 |issue=6 |pages=8 |year=2012 |publisher=National Center for Health Statistics |url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr61/nvsr61_06.pdf |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202154454/http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr61/nvsr61_06.pdf |archivedate=2014-02-02 |df= }} It is the most common cause of death between one month and one year of age. About 90% of cases happen before six months of age, with it being most frequent between two months and four months of age. It is more common in boys than girls.{{cite web|title=How many infants die from SIDS or are at risk for SIDS?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/conditioninfo/pages/risk.aspx|website=National Institute of Child Health and Human Development|accessdate=9 March 2015|date=19 November 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402182125/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/sids/conditioninfo/pages/risk.aspx|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}} ==Definition== SIDS is a [[diagnosis of exclusion]] and should be applied to only those cases in which an infant's death is sudden and unexpected, and remains unexplained after the performance of an adequate [[postmortem]] investigation, including: # an [[autopsy]] (by an experienced pediatric [[pathologist]], if possible); # investigation of the death scene and circumstances of the death; # exploration of the [[medical history]] of the infant and family. After investigation, some of these infant deaths are found to be caused by accidental suffocation, [[hyperthermia]] or [[hypothermia]], neglect or some other defined cause.{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/sids/aboutsuidandsids.htm |title=Sudden Unexpected Infant Death and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome: About SUID and SIDS |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |accessdate=April 16, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420200947/http://www.cdc.gov/sids/aboutsuidandsids.htm |archivedate=April 20, 2016 |df= }} Australia and New Zealand are shifting to the term "sudden unexpected death in infancy" (SUDI) for professional, scientific, and coronial clarity.
The term SUDI is now often used instead of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) because some coroners prefer to use the term 'undetermined' for a death previously considered to be SIDS. This change is causing diagnostic shift in the mortality data.[http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/0/5118C5C5561CEC79CC2573A6000B3BBE NZ Ministry of Health] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212171003/http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/0/5118C5C5561CEC79CC2573A6000B3BBE |date=December 12, 2009 }}
In addition, the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) has recently proposed that such deaths be called "sudden unexpected infant deaths" (SUID) and that SIDS is a subset of SUID.{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/sids/pdf/sudden-unexpected-infant-death.pdf |title=Sudden Unexpected Infant Death |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |accessdate=April 16, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513173510/http://www.cdc.gov/sids/pdf/sudden-unexpected-infant-death.pdf |archivedate=May 13, 2016 |df= }} ===Age=== SIDS has a 4-parameter [[lognormal]] [[age distribution]] that spares infants shortly after birth — the time of maximal risk for almost all other causes of non-trauma infant death. By definition, SIDS deaths occur under the age of one year, with the peak incidence occurring when the infant is at 2 to 4 months of age. This is considered a critical period because the infant's ability to rouse from sleep is not yet mature. ==Risk factors== The cause of SIDS is unknown. Although studies have identified risk factors for SIDS, such as putting infants to bed on their stomachs, there has been little understanding of the syndrome's biological process or its potential causes. The frequency of SIDS does appear to be influenced by social, economic, and cultural factors, such as maternal education, race or ethnicity, and poverty.Pickett, KE, Luo, Y, Lauderdale, DS. Widening Social Inequalities in Risk for Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. ''Am J Public Health'' 2005;94(11):1976–1981. {{DOI|10.2105/AJPH.2004.059063}} SIDS is believed to occur when an infant with an underlying biological vulnerability, who is at a critical development age, is exposed to an external trigger. The following risk factors generally contribute either to the underlying biological vulnerability or represent an external trigger: ===Tobacco smoke=== SIDS rates are higher for infants of mothers who [[Smoking and pregnancy|smoke during pregnancy]].[[Surgeon General of the United States|Office of the Surgeon General of the United States]] [http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/news/speeches/06272006a.html Report on Involuntary Exposure to Tobacco Smoke] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110806133133/http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/news/speeches/06272006a.html |date=2011-08-06 }}([http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/library/secondhandsmoke/report/fullreport.pdf PDF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205173605/http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/library/secondhandsmoke/report/fullreport.pdf |date=2009-02-05 }}) SIDS correlates with levels of [[nicotine]] and derivatives in the infant.{{cite journal |author1=Bajanowski T. |author2=Brinkmann B. |author3=Mitchell E. |author4=Vennemann M. |author5=Leukel H. |author6=Larsch K. |author7=Beike J. |author8=Gesid G. | year = 2008 | title = Nicotine and cotinine in infants dying from sudden infant death syndrome | url = | journal = International journal of legal medicine | volume = 122 | issue = 1| pages = 23–28 | doi = 10.1007/s00414-007-0155-9 | pmid = 17285322 }} Nicotine and derivatives cause significant alterations in fetal neurodevelopment.{{cite journal |vauthors=Lavezzi AM, Corna MF, Matturri L | title = Ependymal alterations in sudden intrauterine unexplained death and sudden infant death syndrome: possible primary consequence of prenatal exposure to cigarette smoking | journal = Neural Dev | volume = 5 | page = 17 | date = July 2010 | pmid = 20642831 | pmc = 2919533 | doi = 10.1186/1749-8104-5-17 | url = http://www.neuraldevelopment.com/content/5//17 }} ===Sleeping=== Placing an infant to sleep while lying on the stomach or the side increases the risk. This increased risk is greatest at two to three months of age. Elevated or reduced room temperature also increases the risk,{{cite journal |vauthors=Moon RY, Horne RS, Hauck FR | title = Sudden infant death syndrome | journal = Lancet | volume = 370 | issue = 9598 | pages = 1578–87 | date = November 2007 | pmid = 17980736 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61662-6 }} as does excessive bedding, clothing, soft sleep surfaces, and stuffed animals.{{cite journal |vauthors=Fleming PJ, Levine MR, Azaz Y, Wigfield R, Stewart AJ | title = Interactions between thermoregulation and the control of respiration in infants: possible relationship to sudden infant death | journal = Acta Paediatr Suppl | volume = 82 | issue = Suppl 389 | pages = 57–9 | date = June 1993 | pmid = 8374195 | doi = 10.1111/j.1651-2227.1993.tb12878.x }} [[Bumper pads]] may increase the risk of SIDS due to the risk of suffocation. They are not recommended for children under one year of age as this risk of suffocation greatly outweighs the risk of head bumping or limbs getting stuck in the bars of the crib. [[Co-sleeping|Sharing a bed]] with parents or siblings increases the risk for SIDS.{{cite journal |vauthors=McIntosh CG, Tonkin SL, Gunn AJ | title = What is the mechanism of sudden infant deaths associated with co-sleeping? | journal = N. Z. Med. J. | volume = 122 | issue = 1307 | pages = 69–75 | year = 2009 | pmid = 20148046 }} This risk is greatest in the first three months of life, when the mattress is soft, when one or more persons share the infant's bed, especially when the bed partners are using drugs or alcohol or are smoking. The risk remains, however, even in parents who do not smoke or use drugs.{{cite journal |last1=Carpenter |first1=R |last2=McGarvey |first2=C |last3=Mitchell |first3=EA |last4=Tappin |first4=DM |last5=Vennemann |first5=MM |last6=Smuk |first6=M |last7=Carpenter |first7=JR |title=Bed sharing when parents do not smoke: is there a risk of SIDS? An individual level analysis of five major case-control studies |url=http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/3/5/e002299 |journal=BMJ Open |volume=3 |issue=5 |year=2013 |pmid=23793691 |doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2012-002299 |pages=e002299 |pmc=3657670 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415043349/http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/3/5/e002299 |archivedate=2016-04-15 |df= }} {{open access}} The [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] thus recommends "room-sharing without bed-sharing", stating that such an arrangement can decrease the risk of SIDS by up to 50%. Furthermore, the Academy recommended against devices marketed to make bed-sharing "safe", such as in-bed co-sleepers.{{cite journal | author = Moon RY | title = SIDS and other sleep-related infant deaths: expansion of recommendations for a safe infant sleeping environment. | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 128 | issue = 5 | pages = 1030–9 | date = November 2011 | pmid = 22007004 | doi = 10.1542/peds.2011-2284 }} ===Breastfeeding=== [[Breastfeeding]] is associated with a lower risk of SIDS.{{cite journal|last1=Hauck|first1=FR|last2=Thompson|first2=JM|last3=Tanabe|first3=KO|last4=Moon|first4=RY|last5=Vennemann|first5=MM|title=Breastfeeding and reduced risk of sudden infant death syndrome: a meta-analysis.|journal=Pediatrics|date=July 2011|volume=128|issue=1|pages=103–10|pmid=21669892|doi=10.1542/peds.2010-3000}} It is not clear if co-sleeping among mothers who breastfeed without any other risk factors increases SIDS risk.{{cite journal|last1=Fleming|first1=PJ|last2=Blair|first2=PS|title=Making informed choices on co-sleeping with your baby.|journal=BMJ (Clinical research ed.)|date=2 February 2015|volume=350|pages=h563|pmid=25643704|doi=10.1136/bmj.h563}} ===Pregnancy and infant factors=== SIDS rates decrease with increasing maternal age, with [[teenage pregnancy|teenage mothers]] at greatest risk.{{cite journal |vauthors=Sullivan FM, Barlow SM | title = Review of risk factors for Sudden Infant Death Syndrome | journal = Paediatric Perinatal Epidemiology | volume = 15 | issue = 2 | pages = 144–200 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11383580 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-3016.2001.00330.x }} Delayed or inadequate [[prenatal care]] also increases risk. Low [[birth weight]] is a significant risk factor. In the United States from 1995 to 1998, the SIDS death rate for infants weighing 1000–1499 g was 2.89/1000, while for a birth weight of 3500–3999 g, it was only 0.51/1000.{{cite journal | author = Hunt CE | title = Small for gestational age infants and sudden infant death syndrome: a confluence of complex conditions | journal = Arch. Dis. Child. Fetal Neonatal Ed. | volume = 92 | issue = 6 | pages = F428–9 | date = November 2007 | pmid = 17951549 | pmc = 2675383 | doi = 10.1136/adc.2006.112243 | url = http://fn.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17951549 }} [[Premature birth]] increases the risk of SIDS death roughly fourfold. From 1995 to 1998, the U.S. SIDS rate for births at 37–39 weeks of [[gestation]] was 0.73/1000, while the SIDS rate for births at 28–31 weeks of gestation was 2.39/1000. [[Anemia]] has also been linked to SIDS{{cite journal |vauthors=Poets CF, Samuels MP, Wardrop CA, Picton-Jones E, Southall DP | title = Reduced haemoglobin levels in infants presenting with apparent life-threatening events—a retrospective investigation | journal = Acta Paediatr. | volume = 81 | issue = 4 | pages = 319–21 | date = April 1992 | pmid = 1606392 | doi = 10.1111/j.1651-2227.1992.tb12234.x }} (note, however, that per item 6 in the list of epidemiologic characteristics below, extent of anemia cannot be evaluated at autopsy because an infant's total [[hemoglobin]] can only be measured during life.{{cite journal |vauthors=Giulian GG, Gilbert EF, Moss RL | title = Elevated fetal hemoglobin levels in sudden infant death syndrome | journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 316 | issue = 18 | pages = 1122–6 | date = April 1987 | pmid = 2437454 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM198704303161804 }}). SIDS incidence rises from zero at birth, is highest from two to four months of age, and declines toward zero after the infant's first year.{{cite journal |author=Mage DT |title=A probability model for the age distribution of SIDS |journal=J Sudden Infant Death Syndrome Infant Mortal |volume=1 |pages=13–31 |year=1996}} ===Genetics=== [[Genetics]] plays a role, as SIDS is more prevalent in males.See [http://wonder.cdc.gov CDC WONDER online database] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424201355/http://wonder.cdc.gov/ |date=2010-04-24 }} and {{cite web |url=http://www3.who.int/whosis/menu.cfm?path=whosis,inds,mort&language=english |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-03-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040627063703/http://www3.who.int/whosis/menu.cfm?path=whosis,inds,mort&language=english |archivedate=2004-06-27 |df= }} for data on SIDS by gender in the US and throughout the world.{{cite journal |vauthors=Mage DT, Donner EM | title = The fifty percent male excess of infant respiratory mortality | journal = Acta Paediatr. | volume = 93 | issue = 9 | pages = 1210–5 | date = September 2004 | pmid = 15384886 | doi = 10.1080/08035250410031305 | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre=article&sid=nlm:pubmed&issn=0803-5253&date=2004&volume=93&issue=9&spage=1210 }} There is a consistent 50% male excess in SIDS per 1000 live births of each sex. Given a 5% male excess birth rate, there appears to be 3.15 male SIDS cases per 2 female, for a male fraction of 0.61. This value of 61% in the US is an average of 57% black male SIDS, 62.2% white male SIDS and 59.4% for all other races combined. Note that when multiracial parentage is involved, infant race is arbitrarily assigned to one category or the other; most often it is chosen by the mother. The [[sex linkage|X-linkage]] hypothesis for SIDS and the male excess in infant mortality have shown that the 50% male excess could be related to a dominant X-linked [[allele]], occurring with a frequency of {{Frac|1|3}} that is protective of [[Cerebral hypoxia|transient cerebral anoxia]]. An unprotected male would occur with a frequency of {{Frac|2|3}} and an unprotected female would occur with a frequency of {{Frac|4|9}}. About 10 to 20% of SIDS cases are believed to be due to [[channelopathies]], which are inherited defects in the [[ion channels]] which play an important role in the contraction of the heart.{{cite journal|last1=Behere|first1=SP|last2=Weindling|first2=SN|title=Inherited arrhythmias: The cardiac channelopathies.|journal=Annals of Pediatric Cardiology|date=2014|volume=8|issue=3|pages=210–20|pmid=26556967|doi=10.4103/0974-2069.164695|pmc=4608198}} ===Alcohol=== Drinking of alcohol by parents is linked to SIDS.{{cite journal|last1=Van Nguyen|first1=JM|last2=Abenhaim|first2=HA|title=Sudden infant death syndrome: review for the obstetric care provider.|journal=American Journal of Perinatology|date=October 2013|volume=30|issue=9|pages=703–14|pmid=23292938|doi=10.1055/s-0032-1331035}} One study found a positive correlation between the two during New Years celebrations and weekends.{{cite journal|last1=Phillips|first1=DP|last2=Brewer|first2=KM|last3=Wadensweiler|first3=P|title=Alcohol as a risk factor for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).|journal=Addiction|date=March 2011|volume=106|issue=3|pages=516–25|pmid=21059188|doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.2010.03199.x|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906181709/|archivedate=2017-09-06|df=}} Another found that [[alcohol use disorder]] was linked to a more than twofold risk.{{cite journal|last1=O'Leary|first1=CM|last2=Jacoby|first2=PJ|last3=Bartu|first3=A|last4=D'Antoine|first4=H|last5=Bower|first5=C|title=Maternal alcohol use and sudden infant death syndrome and infant mortality excluding SIDS.|journal=Pediatrics|date=March 2013|volume=131|issue=3|pages=e770-8|doi=10.1542/peds.2012-1907|pmid=23439895}} ===Other=== There is a tentative link with ''[[Staphylococcus aureus]]'' and ''[[Escherichia coli]]''.{{cite journal |vauthors=Weber MA, Klein NJ, Hartley JC, Lock PE, Malone M, Sebire NJ | title = Infection and sudden unexpected death in infancy: a systematic retrospective case review. | journal = Lancet | volume = 371 | issue = 9627 | pages = 1848–53 | date = May 31, 2008 | pmid = 18514728 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(08)60798-9 }} [[Vaccinations]] do not increase the risk of SIDS; contrarily, they are linked to a 50% lower risk of SIDS.{{cite journal |last1=Vennemann |first1=MM |last2=Höffgen |first2=M |last3=Bajanowski |first3=T |last4=Hense |first4=HW |last5=Mitchell |first5=EA|title=Do immunisations reduce the risk for SIDS? A meta-analysis |journal=Vaccine |date=21 June 2007|volume=25|issue=26|pages=4875–9|pmid=17400342 |doi=10.1016/j.vaccine.2007.02.077}}{{cite web |title=Vaccine Safety: Common Concerns: Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) |url=https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/Concerns/sids.html |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |date=28 August 2015 |accessdate=15 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417194809/http://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/sids.html |archivedate=17 April 2016 |df= }} SIDS has been linked to cold weather with this association believed to be due to over bundling and thus overheating.{{cite web |title=NIH alerts caregivers to increase in SIDS risk during cold weather |url=https://www.nih.gov/news-events/news-releases/nih-alerts-caregivers-increase-sids-risk-during-cold-weather |website=National Institutes of Health (NIH) |accessdate=27 July 2018 |language=en |date=3 September 2015}} A 1998 report found that antimony- and phosphorus-containing compounds used as fire retardants in [[PVC]] and other cot mattress materials are not a cause of SIDS.See [https://web.archive.org/web/20001026033455/http://www.sids.org.uk/fsid/limerick.htm FSID Press release]. The report also states that toxic gas cannot be generated from antimony in mattresses and that babies suffered SIDS on mattresses that did not contain the compound. A set of risk factors SIS has been identified with: increasing SIDS rate with live birth order; low increased risk of SIDS in subsequent siblings of SIDS; apparent life-threatening events (ALTE) are not a risk factor for subsequent SIDS; SIDS risk is greatest during sleep.{{cite journal |vauthors=Mage DT, Donner EM |title=Is SIDS at Borkmann's Point? |journal=[[Medical Hypotheses]] |volume=1 |issue=2/3 |pages=131–7 |year=2004 }}{{ums|date=November 2017}} ==Differential diagnosis== Some conditions that are often undiagnosed and could be confused with or [[comorbidity|comorbid]] with SIDS include: * [[medium-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase deficiency]] (MCAD deficiency);{{cite journal |vauthors=Yang Z, Lantz PE, Ibdah JA | title = Post-mortem analysis for two prevalent beta-oxidation mutations in sudden infant death | journal = Pediatr Int | volume = 49 | issue = 6 | pages = 883–7 | date = December 2007 | pmid = 18045290 | doi = 10.1111/j.1442-200X.2007.02478.x | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre=article&sid=nlm:pubmed&issn=1328-8067&date=2007&volume=49&issue=6&spage=883 }} * infant [[botulism]];{{cite journal |vauthors=Nevas M, Lindström M, Virtanen A, Hielm S, Kuusi M, Arnon SS, Vuori E, Korkeala H | title = Infant botulism acquired from household dust presenting as sudden infant death syndrome | journal = J. Clin. Microbiol. | volume = 43 | issue = 1 | pages = 511–3 | date = January 2005 | pmid = 15635031 | pmc = 540168 | doi = 10.1128/JCM.43.1.511-513.2005 }} * [[long QT syndrome]] (accounting for less than 2% of cases);{{cite journal |vauthors=Millat G, Kugener B, Chevalier P, Chahine M, Huang H, Malicier D, Rodriguez-Lafrasse C, Rousson R | title = Contribution of long-QT syndrome genetic variants in sudden infant death syndrome | journal = Pediatr Cardiol | volume = 30 | issue = 4 | pages = 502–9 | date = May 2009 | pmid = 19322600 | doi = 10.1007/s00246-009-9417-2 }} * ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'' bacterial infections;{{cite journal |vauthors=Stray-Pedersen A, Vege A, Rognum TO | title = ''Helicobacter pylori'' antigen in stool is associated with SIDS and sudden infant deaths due to infectious disease | journal = Pediatr. Res. | volume = 64 | issue = 4 | pages = 405–10 | date = October 2008 | pmid = 18535491 | doi = 10.1203/PDR.0b013e31818095f7 | url = http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0031-3998&volume=64&issue=4&spage=405 }} * [[shaken baby syndrome]] and other forms of [[child abuse]];{{cite journal |vauthors=Bajanowski T, Vennemann M, Bohnert M, Rauch E, Brinkmann B, Mitchell EA | title = Unnatural causes of sudden unexpected deaths initially thought to be sudden infant death syndrome | journal = Int. J. Legal Med. | volume = 119 | issue = 4 | pages = 213–6 | date = July 2005 | pmid = 15830244 | doi = 10.1007/s00414-005-0538-8 }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Du Chesne A, Bajanowski T, Brinkmann B | title = [Homicides without clues in children] | language = German | journal = Arch Kriminol | volume = 199 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 21–6 | year = 1997 | pmid = 9157833 }} *[[overlaying]], child smothering during carer's sleep{{cite journal |vauthors=Williams FL, Lang GA, Mage DT | title = Sudden unexpected infant deaths in Dundee, 1882–1891: overlying or SIDS? | journal = Scottish medical journal | volume = 46 | issue = 2 | pages = 43–47 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11394337 }} For example, an infant with MCAD deficiency could have died by "classical SIDS" if found swaddled and prone with head covered in an overheated room where [[smoking and pregnancy|parents were smoking]]. Genes indicating susceptibility to MCAD and Long QT syndrome do not protect an infant from dying of classical SIDS. Therefore, presence of a susceptibility gene, such as for MCAD, means the infant may have died either from SIDS or from MCAD deficiency. It is currently impossible for the pathologist to distinguish between them. A 2010 study looked at 554 autopsies of infants in [[North Carolina]] that listed SIDS as the cause of death, and suggested that many of these deaths may have been due to accidental suffocation. The study found that 69% of autopsies listed other possible risk factors that could have led to death, such as unsafe bedding or sleeping with adults.{{cite web |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/sids/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811030214/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/sids/ |archivedate=2011-08-11 |df= }} Several instances of [[infanticide]] have been uncovered where the diagnosis was originally SIDS.{{cite book |title=Cradle of Death: A Shocking True Story of a Mother, Multiple Murder, and SIDS |year=2000 |isbn=0-312-97302-0 |first=John |last=Glatt |publisher=Macmillan}}{{cite book |title=While Innocents Slept: A Story of Revenge, Murder, and SIDS |year=2002 |isbn=0-312-97517-1 |first=Adrian |last=Havill |publisher=Macmillan}} Estimate of the percentage of SIDS deaths that are actually infanticide vary from less than 1% to up to 5% of cases.{{cite journal | author = Hymel KP | title = Distinguishing sudden infant death syndrome from child abuse fatalities. | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 118 | issue = 1 | pages = 421–7 | date = July 2006 | pmid = 16818592 | doi = 10.1542/peds.2006-1245 }} Some have underestimated the risk of two SIDS deaths occurring in the same family and the [[Royal Statistical Society]] issued a media release refuting this expert testimony in one UK case in which the conviction was subsequently overturned.[http://www.rss.org.uk/main.asp?page=1225 "About Statistics and the Law"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902044706/http://www.rss.org.uk/main.asp?page=1225 |date=2007-09-02 }} (Website). Royal Statistical Society. (2001-10-23) Retrieved on 2007-09-22 ==Prevention== A number of measures have been found to be effective in preventing SIDS including changing the sleeping position, breastfeeding, limiting soft bedding, immunizing the infant and using pacifiers. The use of electronic monitors has not been found to be useful as a preventative strategy. The effect that fans might have on the risk of SIDS has not been studied well enough to make any recommendation about them. Evidence regarding [[swaddling]] is unclear regarding SIDS. A 2016 review found tentative evidence that swaddling increases risk of SIDS, especially among babies placed on their stomachs or side while sleeping.{{cite journal|last1=Pease|first1=AS|last2=Fleming|first2=PJ|last3=Hauck|first3=FR|last4=Moon|first4=RY|last5=Horne|first5=RS|last6=L'Hoir|first6=MP|last7=Ponsonby|first7=AL|last8=Blair|first8=PS|title=Swaddling and the Risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome: A Meta-analysis.|journal=Pediatrics|date=June 2016|volume=137|issue=6|doi=10.1542/peds.2015-3275|pmid=27244847|quote=Limited evidence suggested swaddling risk increased with infant age and was associated with a twofold risk for infants aged >6 months.|page=e20153275}} ===Sleep positioning=== [[File:back to sleep plot.png|thumb|A plot of SIDS rate from 1988 to 2006]] Sleeping on the back has been found to reduce the risk of SIDS.{{cite journal | author = Mitchell EA | title = SIDS: past, present and future. | journal = Acta Paediatrica | volume = 98 | issue = 11 | pages = 1712–9 | date = November 2009 | pmid = 19807704 | doi = 10.1111/j.1651-2227.2009.01503.x }} It is thus recommended by the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] and promoted as a best practice by the US [[National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] (NICHD) "[[Safe to Sleep]]" campaign. The incidence of SIDS has fallen in a number of countries in which this recommendation has been widely adopted.{{cite journal |vauthors=Mitchell EA, Hutchison L, Stewart AW | title = The continuing decline in SIDS mortality | journal = Arch Dis Child | volume = 92 | issue = 7 | pages = 625–6 | date = July 2007 | pmid = 17405855 | pmc = 2083749 | doi = 10.1136/adc.2007.116194 }} Sleeping on the back does not appear to increase the risk of choking even in those with [[gastroesophageal reflux disease]]. While infants in this position may sleep more lightly this is not harmful. Sharing the same room as one's parents but in a different bed may decrease the risk by half. ===Pacifiers=== The use of [[pacifier]]s appears to decrease the risk of SIDS although the reason is unclear. The [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] considers pacifier use to prevent SIDS to be reasonable. Pacifiers do not appear to affect breastfeeding in the first four months, even though this is a common misconception.{{Cite journal|last=Jaafar|first=Sharifah Halimah|last2=Ho|first2=Jacqueline J.|last3=Jahanfar|first3=Shayesteh|last4=Angolkar|first4=Mubashir|date=2016-08-30|title=Effect of restricted pacifier use in breastfeeding term infants for increasing duration of breastfeeding|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue=8|pages=CD007202|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD007202.pub4|issn=1469-493X|pmid=27572944}} ===Bedding=== Product safety experts advise against using pillows, overly soft mattresses, sleep positioners, bumper pads (crib bumpers), stuffed animals, or fluffy bedding in the crib and recommend instead dressing the child warmly and keeping the crib "naked."{{cite web |title=What Can Be Done? |publisher=American SIDS Institute |url=http://www.sids.org/nprevent.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030621224728/http://www.sids.org/nprevent.htm |archivedate=2003-06-21 |df= }} Blankets or other clothing should not be placed over a baby's head.{{cite journal|first1=Task Force on Sudden Infant Death|last1=Syndrome|title=SIDS and Other Sleep-Related Infant Deaths: Updated 2016 Recommendations for a Safe Infant Sleeping Environment|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2016/10/20/peds.2016-2938|journal=Pediatrics|date=24 October 2016|issn=0031-4005|pages=e20162938|doi=10.1542/peds.2016-2938|volume=138|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025013544/http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2016/10/20/peds.2016-2938|archivedate=25 October 2016|df=}} ===Sleep sacks=== In colder environments where bedding is required to maintain a baby's body temperature, the use of a "[[Sleeping bag#Infant use|baby sleep bag]]" or "sleep sack" is becoming more popular. This is a soft bag with holes for the baby's arms and head. A zipper allows the bag to be closed around the baby. A study published in the ''European Journal of Pediatrics'' in August 1998{{cite journal |vauthors=L'Hoir MP, Engelberts AC, van Well GT, McClelland S, Westers P, Dandachli T, Mellenbergh GJ, Wolters WH, Huber J | title = Risk and preventive factors for cot death in The Netherlands, a low-incidence country | journal = Eur. J. Pediatr. | volume = 157 | issue = 8 | pages = 681–8 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9727856 | doi = 10.1007/s004310050911 }} has shown the protective effects of a sleep sack as reducing the incidence of turning from back to front during sleep, reinforcing putting a baby to sleep on its back for placement into the sleep sack and preventing bedding from coming up over the face which leads to increased temperature and carbon dioxide rebreathing. They conclude in their study, "The use of a sleeping-sack should be particularly promoted for infants with a low birth weight." The American Academy of Pediatrics also recommends them as a type of bedding that warms the baby without covering its head.{{cite web |title=The Changing Concept of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome: Diagnostic Coding Shifts, Controversies Regarding the Sleeping Environment, and New Variables to Consider in Reducing Risk |publisher=[[American Academy of Pediatrics]] |accessdate=2008-11-06 |url=http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/pediatrics;116/5/1245#SEC15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203234922/http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/pediatrics%3B116/5/1245#SEC15 |archivedate=3 December 2008 |df= }} ===Vaccination=== A large investigation into [[DPT vaccine|diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination]] and potential SIDS association by Berlin School of Public Health, Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin concluded: "Increased DTP immunisation coverage is associated with decreased SIDS mortality. Current recommendations on timely DTP immunisation should be emphasised to prevent not only specific infectious diseases but also potentially SIDS."{{cite journal|last1=Müller-Nordhorn|first1=Jacqueline|last2=Hettler-Chen|first2=Chih-Mei|last3=Keil|first3=Thomas|last4=Muckelbauer|first4=Rebecca|title=Association between sudden infant death syndrome and diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis immunisation: an ecological study|journal=BMC Pediatrics|date=28 January 2015|volume=15|issue=1|doi=10.1186/s12887-015-0318-7}} Many other studies have also reached conclusions that vaccinations reduce the risk of SIDS. Studies generally show that SIDS risk is approximately halved by vaccinations.{{cite journal|last1=Mitchell|first1=E A|last2=Stewart|first2=A W|last3=Clements|first3=M|title=Immunisation and the sudden infant death syndrome. New Zealand Cot Death Study Group.|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|date=1 December 1995|volume=73|issue=6|pages=498–501|doi=10.1136/adc.73.6.498|pmc=1511439}}{{cite journal|last1=Fleming|first1=P. J|title=The UK accelerated immunisation programme and sudden unexpected death in infancy: case-control study|journal=BMJ|date=7 April 2001|volume=322|issue=7290|pages=822–822|doi=10.1136/bmj.322.7290.822}}{{cite journal|title=Do immunisations reduce the risk for SIDS? A meta-analysis|first=M.M.T. |last=Vennemann |first2=M. |last2=Höffgen |first3=T. |last3=Bajanowski |first4=H.-W. |last4=Hense |first5=E.A. |last5=Mitchell|journal=Vaccine|volume=25|issue=26|pages=4875–9|date=2007|doi=10.1016/j.vaccine.2007.02.077 |pmid=17400342}}{{cite journal|last1=Hoffman|first1=HJ|last2=Hunter|first2=JC|last3=Damus|first3=K|last4=Pakter|first4=J|last5=Peterson|first5=DR|last6=van Belle|first6=G|last7=Hasselmeyer|first7=EG|title=Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis immunization and sudden infant death: results of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Cooperative Epidemiological Study of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome risk factors.|journal=Pediatrics|date=April 1987|volume=79|issue=4|pages=598–611|pmid=3493477}}{{cite journal|last1=Carvajal|first1=A|last2=Caro-Patón|first2=T|last3=Martín de Diego|first3=I|last4=Martín Arias|first4=LH|last5=Alvarez Requejo|first5=A|last6=Lobato|first6=A|title=[DTP vaccine and infant sudden death syndrome. Meta-analysis].|journal=Medicina clinica|date=4 May 1996|volume=106|issue=17|pages=649–52|pmid=8691909}} ==Management== Families who are impacted by SIDS should be offered emotional support and grief counseling.{{cite journal |vauthors=Adams SM, Good MW, Defranco GM | title = Sudden infant death syndrome | journal = Am Fam Physician | volume = 79 | issue = 10 | pages = 870–4 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19496386 }} The experience and manifestation of grief at the loss of an infant are impacted by cultural and individual differences.{{cite journal |vauthors=Koopmans L, Wilson T, Cacciatore J, etal |title=Support for mothers, fathers and families after perinatal death |journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |date=Jun 13, 2013 |volume=6 |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD000452.pub3}} ==Epidemiology== Globally SIDS resulted in about 22,000 deaths {{as of|2010|lc=y}}, down from 30,000 deaths in 1990.{{cite journal |vauthors=Lozano R, Naghavi M, Foreman K, Lim S, Shibuya K, Aboyans V, Abraham J, Adair T, Aggarwal R, Ahn SY, etal | title = Global and regional mortality from 235 causes of death for 20 age groups in 1990 and 2010: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2010. | journal = Lancet | volume = 380 | issue = 9859 | pages = 2095–128 | date = Dec 15, 2012 | pmid = 23245604 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(12)61728-0 }} Rates vary significantly by population from 0.05 per 1000 in Hong Kong to 6.7 per 1000 in American Indians.{{cite journal | author = Sharma BR | title = Sudden infant death syndrome: a subject of medicolegal research. | journal = The American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology | volume = 28 | issue = 1 | pages = 69–72 | date = March 2007 | pmid = 17325469 | doi = 10.1097/01.paf.0000220934.18700.ef }} SIDS was responsible for 0.54 deaths per 1,000 live births in the US in 2005.{{cite web |url=http://wonder.cdc.gov |title=Cdc Wonder |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-04-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424201355/http://wonder.cdc.gov/ |archivedate=2010-04-24 |df= }} It is responsible for far fewer deaths than congenital disorders and disorders related to short gestation, though it is the leading cause of death in healthy infants after one month of age. SIDS deaths in the US decreased from 4,895 in 1992 to 2,247 in 2004.Bowman L, Hargrove T. Exposing Sudden Infant Death In America. Scripps Howard News Service. {{cite web |url=http://dailycamera.com/news/2007/oct/08/saving-babies-exposing-sudden-infant-death-in/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226153439/http://www.dailycamera.com/news/2007/oct/08/saving-babies-exposing-sudden-infant-death-in/ |archivedate=2009-02-26 |df= }} But, during a similar time period, 1989 to 2004, SIDS being listed as the cause of death for sudden infant death (SID) decreased from 80% to 55%. According to John Kattwinkel, chairman of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Special Task Force on SIDS "A lot of us are concerned that the rate (of SIDS) isn't decreasing significantly, but that a lot of it is just code shifting". ===Race=== [[File:US SIDS rates race 2009.png|thumb|Rates of SIDS by race/ethnicity in the U.S., 2009, CDC, 2013]] In 2013, there are persistent disparities in SIDS deaths among racial and ethnic groups in the U.S. In 2009, the rates of death range from 20.3 per 100,000 live births for Asian/Pacific Islander to 119.2 per 100,000 live births for American Indians/Alaska Native. African American infants have a 24% greater risk of having a SIDS related death{{cite journal|last1=Powers|first1=D. A.|last2=Song|first2=S.|title=Absolute change in cause-specific infant mortality for blacks and whites in the US: 1983–2002|journal=tion Research and Policy Review|date=2009|volume=28|issue=6|pages=817–851|doi=10.1007/s11113-009-9130-0}} and experience a 2.5 greater incidence of SIDS than in Caucasian infants.{{cite journal|last1=Pollack|first1=H. A.|last2=Frohna|first2=J. G.|title=A competing risk model of sudden infant death syndrome incidence in two US birth cohorts|journal=The Journal of Pediatrics|date=2001|volume=138|issue=5|pages=661–667|doi=10.1067/mpd.2001.112248|pmid=11343040}} Rates are per 100,000 live births and enable more accurate comparison across groups of different total population size. Research suggests that factors which contribute more directly to SIDS risk—maternal age, exposure to smoking, safe sleep practices, etc.—vary by racial and ethnic group and therefore risk exposure also varies by these groups. Risk factors associated with prone sleeping patterns of African American families include mother's age, household poverty index, rural/urban status of residence, and infant's age. More than 50% of African American infants were placed in non-recommended sleeping positions according to a study completed in South Carolina.{{cite journal|last1=Smith|first1=M. G.|last2=Liu|first2=J.|last3=Helms|first3=K. H.|last4=Wilkerson|first4=K. L.|title=Racial differences in trends and predictors of infant sleep positioning in south carolina, 1996–2007|journal=Maternal and Child Health Journal|date=2012|volume=15|issue=1|pages=72–82|doi=10.1007/s10995-010-0718-0}} Cultural factors can be protective as well as problematic.Brathwaite-Fisher, T, Bronheim, S. Cultural Competence and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome and Other Infant Death: A Review of the Literature from 1990–2000. '''The Baby-Roast''', also known as '''The Hippy Babysitter''' and '''The Cooked Baby''',<ref name="Brunvand"/> is an [[urban legend]] in which a baby is roasted alive at home, usually during the absence of a parent. ''[[The Straight Dope]]'', a newspaper column devoted to exposing myths, reported that it "is one of the classic urban legends",<ref>{{cite web|date=February 3, 1984 |url=http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/194/did-a-stoned-babysitter-once-microwave-a-baby |title=Did a stoned babysitter once microwave a baby? |publisher=''[[The Straight Dope]]'' }}</ref> however, there have been real life instances where babies have been roasted.
==Plot== In some versions, the baby is accidentally cooked when miscommunication occurs. For example, "put the turkey in the oven and the baby in the bed" is wrongly heard as "put the baby in the oven and the turkey in the bed".<ref name="Brunvand"/> Other variants set out that the doer of the deed was drug or alcohol-induced or an insane individual.<ref name="Brunvand2001"/> In the end, the roasted baby is sometimes served as food to be consumed by the parents.<ref name="Brunvand2001">{{cite book|author=Jan Harold Brunvand|authorlink=Jan Harold Brunvand|title=The Truth Never Stands in the Way of a Good Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PhkINW48_J0C&pg=PA55|year=2001|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-07004-4|pages=55–}}</ref>
The person who roasts the baby is usually a babysitter or the baby's sibling.<ref name="Brunvand">{{cite book|author=Jan Harold Brunvand|authorlink=Jan Harold Brunvand|title=Encyclopedia of Urban Legends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H8Kk7bS66jMC&pg=PA26|date=1 January 2001|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-076-5|pages=26–}}</ref>
==Documented occurrences== In real life, there have been documented occurrences of babies being roasted, though by family members instead of strange babysitters. When Virginian Elizabeth Renee Otte roasted her baby in 1999,<ref>{{cite news|title=Mother Charged in Baby's Death |last=Timberg|first=Craig|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/local/daily/sept99/microwave.htm|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=September 28, 1999|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref> the incident was cited as causing the legend to become true. In November 2006, a second case of real-life baby-roasting was reported.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/11/28/mom_microwaves_baby/ |title=Mom cooks baby in microwave oven - police |date=November 28, 2006 |first=Thomas C. |last=Greene |newspaper=[[The Register]] }}</ref>
In February 2012, Ka Yang of California was charged with roasting her seven-week-old baby to death in a microwave. In her defence, she claimed she was having a "seizure fit" when it happened.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2104988/Mother-accused-murdering-baby-putting-microwave-minutes-face-trial.html |title=Mother 'burned her baby to death in microwave because she was having a seizure fit' |date=February 23, 2012 }}</ref> In May 2012, a British citizen was arrested by Thai police after being found in possession of six corpses of roasted infants, some wrapped in [[gold leaf]], reportedly in conformity with a "black magic ritual".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/18/11755862-thai-police-arrest-man-after-babies-bodies-found-roasted-wrapped-in-gold-leaf?lite |title=Thai police arrest man after babies' bodies found roasted, wrapped in gold leaf |date=May 12, 2013 |newspaper=msn }}</ref> In [[Siberia]] in January 2013, a roasted, dismembered baby was found by its mother, the alleged perpetrator being the infant's intoxicated uncle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2267723/Mother-finds-dead-baby-daughter-roasting-oven-chopped-drunk-uncle.html |last=Stewart |first=Will |title=Drunk uncle 'chopped up 18-month-old niece then roasted body parts in the oven' while looking after toddler for her mother |date=January 24, 2013 }}</ref>
On November 16, 2015, a one-year old baby, J'Zyra Thompson, died after her three-year-old sibling put her in the oven and cooked her alive. Their mother, Racqual Thompson, left her four kids at home, which included a five-year-old and a two-year-old, when she went to pick up a pizza. When they returned home, Thompson found J'Zyra's body cooked in the oven. Thompson and her boyfriend of ten months, 21-year-old Cornell Malone, were charged with endangering a child and are awaiting trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox5dc.com/news/national/55113771-story |last=Damali |first=Keith |title=Mother speaks only on FOX after baby dies in oven |date=November 20, 2015 }}</ref>
In March 2016, a 35-year-old mother in Texas showed up naked at her neighbor's door with her partially burned and naked 2-year-old daughter. When police arrived, she confessed that she had put the girl in the oven along with a cat she had recently shot dead, while making sexual advances toward an officer and singing praise to God. According to an affidavit from the [[Texas Department of Family and Protective Services]], she seemed unconcerned with her daughter while in hospital and jail, where she was charged with injury to a child with serious bodily injury and tested positive for alcohol, marijuana and methamphetamine. The girl was put in foster care.<ref>[http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2016/03/mother-who-put-daughter-in-oven.html/ "Glen Rose mother was high before she put daughter in oven, officials say", by Claire Z. Cardona, ''Dallas News Crime Blog'']</ref>
==In popular culture== In the 1979 [[blaxploitation]] film ''[[Disco Godfather|Avenging Disco Godfather]]'', a [[Phencyclidine|PCP]] addict claims to have honey-roasted her baby for her family's [[Easter]] dinner, ostensibly so the baby's crying wouldn't spoil the occasion.
In August 2009, a joke advertisement showcasing a "body part roaster" "specially designed to roast infants and other human morsels" surfaced on the website of retailer [[Sears.com]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/08/21/sears_baby_roaster/ |newspaper=[[The Register]] |date=August 21, 2009 |last=Goodin |first=Dan |title=Baby-roasting BBQ pulled from Sears site }}</ref>
The song 'Babysitter on Acid' by the all-female punk rock band, [[Lunachicks]] is a retelling of the Urban Legend. The teenage babysitter, under the influence of drugs, roasts the baby in the oven and tells the mother over the phone that "Wanna know how the baby is? / Don't worry, she's almost done". The song was released on their 1990 album ''[[Babysitters On Acid]]''.
